image.altText: Australian banknotes, mostly $50 bills, strewn over a flat surface.

props.synopsis: At least 150 Australian Taxation Office officials have been investigated as part of a GST fraud crackdown, resulting in "employment terminations and criminal proceedings", according to a new report from Australia's auditor-general.

title.children: 'Fraudsters evolving': 150 ATO officials investigated in TikTok GST fraud scheme

image.altText: A fallen tree crushes powerlines on a road.

props.synopsis: Regional Victorian communities around the Grampians National Park have been threatened by bushfires started by lightning strikes, as a thunderstorm topples trees and leaves thousands without power in Melbourne.

title.children: Destructive storms sweep Victoria as bushfires threaten Grampians communities

image.altText: Ronald Liu sits on a step in Western Sydney with a cigarette in hand

props.synopsis: Ronald Liu considers himself lucky after spending five days on the street. He is among a growing number of people experiencing homelessness in New South Wales, with instances rising as much as 127 per cent in some areas.Â

title.children: Homelessness 'crisis' rises as much as 127pc in some areas of NSW

image.altText: Search for Samantha Murphy

props.synopsis: In Ballarat's bushland pinpointing a phone signal is hard, so apparently is falling down a mine shaft. So what could have happened to missing mother of three Samantha Murphy?

title.children: Former detective believes police investigating Samantha Murphy disappearance should look at suspects from year-old attack

image.altText: Daniel sits in a black shirt and thick black glasses surrounded by Indigenous art

props.synopsis: Daniel McDonald said he was let down by the health system. Advocates say this is a common occurrence for First Nations people with disabilities. Funding for disability services was left out of today's Closing the Gap Implementation Plan.Â

title.children: Daniel wounded himself and was bleeding out but calling an ambulance was not an option

image.altText: An orange haze hangs in the air over bushland.

props.synopsis: As bushfires continued to rage in Victoria's west, residents were also been hit with major power outages from severe thunderstorms.

title.children: Half a million Victorians lose power as bushfires, storms wreak havoc â as it happened

image.altText: Swimmers at Sydney's Coogee Beach 260124

props.synopsis: Clinicians, patient organisations and medical researchers are updating advice around sun exposure to explicitly recognise different skin types.

title.children: New sun safety advice has been developed for diverse skin types. Here's what it says

image.altText: Blond woman in a sparkly suit flexing her muscles

props.synopsis: Taylor Swift fans have reported having their Ticketek accounts hacked and concert tickets stolen right underneath their noses, just days before the pop star begins her Melbourne shows.

title.children: Australian Swifties have Ticketek accounts hacked and tickets stolen days out from Eras tour

image.altText: A young white woman teaching a primary school class

props.synopsis: A reading revolution at a small, disadvantaged public school in regional Victoria could provide the blueprint for turning around alarming literacy rates in Australia's 10,000 primary schools.

title.children: As the 'reading wars' raged, this school made a teaching change. The results were profound

image.altText: Shane Drumgold holding a folder walking into ACAT.

props.synopsis: Lawyers for former ACT top prosecutor Shane Drumgold argue The Australian journalist Janet Albrechtsen "infected" bias into the mind of Bruce Lehrmann prosecution inquiry chair Walter Sofronoff, whose final report made scathing findings about Mr Drumgold's conduct.

title.children: Journalist 'infected' Bruce Lehrmann inquiry head with bias against top prosecutor, court hears

image.altText: Barnaby Joyce img 2023

props.synopsis: The image of Barnaby Joyce, sprawled drunk on a Canberra footpath during a parliament sitting week, has raised uncomfortable questions for the political class about standards of behaviour and whether those expectations are consistently applied across gender and race, writes Patricia Karvelas.

title.children: The image of Barnaby Joyce on the footpath sparks questions about double standards

image.altText: A green park with a bridge and mulch

props.synopsis: The City of Sydney found bonded and friable asbestos at three parks across the inner-city area, near Broadway, Surry Hills and Central Station. As more locations are added to the growing list.

title.children: High risk type of asbestos found in contaminated mulch at a Sydney dog park

image.altText: Children and adults swimming in blue water with a rocky platform in the background

props.synopsis: NSW has recorded nearly 500 cases ofÂ cryptosporidiosis this year, which is usually contracted by swimming in or swallowing water containing parasites.

title.children: NSW Health urge those with diarrhoea not to swim as cryptosporidiosis cases surge

image.altText: Exterior of a white courthouse building, viewed from the street.

props.synopsis: A 26-year-old woman charged with bestiality offences has faced court supported by her parents, while her co-accused husband did not appear due to health issues.

title.children: Married couple charged with bestiality offences at rural NSW property

image.altText: A platypus diving nose first underwater

props.synopsis: A new platypus haven at Taronga Western Plains Zoo in Dubbo will aid conservation efforts by providing a home for up to 65 of the animals during drought, bushfire and flood.

title.children: Hopes $12m platypus refuge can help halt decline of iconic species

image.altText: Three Aboriginal boys seen from behind.

props.synopsis: 16 years on from Kevin Rudd's apology to the Stolen Generations, statistics show Indigenous children are still being removed from their families at a significant rate â and that the rate is worsening.

title.children: 'A national disgrace': Advocates call for more action to close the gap on First Nations out-of-home care

image.altText: Morgan Riddle holds her thumb and index finger close together while in the crowd at Taylor Fritz's Australian Open match.

props.synopsis: Morgan Riddle says she suffered a panic attack after being harassed at the Super Bowl, crystallising troubling findings from multiple studies around the world about sexual and domestic violence around sporting events.

title.children: Morgan Riddle's 'incessant' and 'scary' harassment at the Super Bowl backs up what we've known for years

image.altText: A middle aged man in a light blue shirt and dark blazer clasps his hands mid-speech.

props.synopsis: Jeremy Rockliff's Liberal government was plunged into minority in May when two MPs defected to the crossbench. After several days of intense speculation, Mr Rockliff says he will ask the governor for an early election.

title.children: Tasmanian Premier Jeremy Rockliff intends to call a state election tomorrow

image.altText: Michael sits at the table in a burgundy suit jacket and floral shirt

props.synopsis: It is 16 years since then-prime minister Kevin Rudd apologised to the Stolen Generations, but survivors say "not a great deal has happened since".

title.children: How a Stolen Generations survivor became 'one of the lucky ones'

image.altText: A young, shirtless man with curly blonde hair stands in front of a bushy valley.

props.synopsis: An inquest into the 2021 death of a Melbourne man near Byron Bay has heard police initially in charge of the investigation did not gather potentially relevant DNA evidence or CCTV footage.

title.children: DNA not collected during probe into mysterious death of young man near Byron Bay, inquest hears

image.altText: optus 'yes' sign on glass fronted office block

props.synopsis:
There are fiery exchanges in the Senate over the Albanese government's handling of last year's massive Optus outage, which left millions without coverage and thousands unable to make emergency calls.
Â

title.children: 'This is the bit that matters': Opposition grills department over Optus's failing triple-0 calls

image.altText: a man wearing protective clothing holding a hive of bees

props.synopsis: It has been nearly five months since Australia gave up trying to eradicate varroa mite, with a national plan now locked in to slow its spread.

title.children: 'Not perfect' plan formed to slow bee parasite's spread across Australia

image.altText: An old bridge over five lanes of road traffic

props.synopsis: A rail bridge that has not been used for more than 30 years is set to be transformed into a pedestrian and cycle path to connect residents to green space across some of Sydney's busiest roadways.

title.children: Unused Abattoirs Branch rail bridge spanning 13 lanes of Great Western Hwy, M4 to become cycle link

image.altText: David Anderson answers questions while facing a senate hearing

props.synopsis: The managing director of the ABC has avoided answering questions about the sacking of journalist Antoinette Lattouf, citing legal advice that doing so could prejudice the hearing of the matter before the employment tribunal.

title.children: ABC managing director faces Senate questions on Lattouf case, Gaza coverage

image.altText: A silhouette of a person in a hoodie over wetlands at sunset.

props.synopsis: Jade has lost four family members to suicide. She isÂ one of hundreds of First Nations people grieving for loved ones as the rate at which Indigenous people taking their own lives continues to rise.Â

title.children: 'It is getting worse every year': Indigenous Australian suicide rates on the rise

image.altText: Kim Keon Hee sits with her husband Yoon Suk Yeol.

props.synopsis: Secret camera footage appearing to show South Korea's first lady accepting an expensive Dior handbag threatens to impact her corruption-busting husband's election campaign. And it's not even Kim Keon Hee's first scandal.Â

title.children: Why has a designer Dior handbag shaken up South Korean politics?

image.altText: A woman with brown hair in a suit jacket looks serious.

props.synopsis: Lisa Wilkinson tells the Federal Court she learned she was being sued for defamation by Bruce Lehrmann from a newspaper article, as she seeks legal costs from Network Ten to cover last year's 20-day trial.

title.children: Lisa Wilkinson says she was 'left alone' by Network Ten to fight accusations of 'derailing' rape trial of Bruce Lehrmann

image.altText: James Tsindos in his school uniform.

props.synopsis: James Tsindos, 17, was unaware the food he ordered from an online app contained nuts before he died from anaphylaxis, a Victorian coroner has heard.

title.children: Coroner to examine food delivery app regulations after teen dies from nut allergy

image.altText: Morrison and Macron at a table in the garden.

props.synopsis: Scott Morrison reveals the covert diplomatic manoeuvres behind the biggest deal of his prime ministership and how he kept it a secret from the man who could torpedo it.

title.children: 'I don't think, I know': The story behind the infamous French sledge about Scott Morrison

image.altText: Two men share a joke while walking in a park.

props.synopsis: WA's revised GST deal is set to cost the federal government $50 billion over a decade, not $39 billion as estimated, economists say, warning that it's not justified and should be changed.

title.children: 'Worst public policy decision of the century': Economists slam WA GST deal

image.altText: A gas cylinder on fire

props.synopsis: Fire crews are using drones to monitor a fire at the BlueScope steel works in Port Kembla in the Illawarra.Â

title.children: Worker injured as highly volatile fuel explodes at Port Kembla steel works

image.altText: A woman with black hair and wearing a mask and jumper holds her fist in the air surrounded by a crowd of protesters.

props.synopsis: The Myanmar junta's decision to begin enforcing a conscription law first enacted 14 years ago is an attack on the country's young people, a "pronouncement of psychotic resolve" andÂ likely to have unintended consequences, analysts say.

title.children: Myanmar's move to enforce military conscription to have 'unintended consequences'

image.altText: A young man in a suit with no tie grimaces as he sits, listening, in the house of representatives

props.synopsis: Labor and the Greens have dug their trenches in preparation for what looms as another lengthy battle in their housing war â this time over a scheme that would see the government co-purchase houses with low-income households.

title.children: Help to Buy looks like round two in the Labor-Greens housing wars. What's it about?

image.altText: A group of people stand before desks covered in paper in large room, facing fowards. One person, Adila Hassim, faces the camera.

props.synopsis: When Adila Hassim represented South Africa in its ICJ case against Israel, she was struck by the overwhelming sense that the courtroom is not a place for women. She's one of many prominent voices now calling for change in the world's highest court.

title.children: In the International Court of Justice, which is hearing allegations of genocide against Israel, where are all the women?
